user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ConsoleTask_Entry:
```c
static void *OS_ConsoleTask_Entry(void *arg)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t           local_arg;
    OS_impl_console_internal_record_t *local;
    OS_object_token_t                  token;

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    local_arg.opaque_arg = arg;
    if (OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONSOLE, local_arg.id, &token) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        local = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_console_table, token);

        /* Loop forever (unless shutdown is set) */
        while (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER)
        {
            OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl(&token);
            sem_wait(&local->data_sem);
        }
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }
    return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ConsoleTask_Entry:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_console_internal_record_t OS_impl_console_table[OS_MAX_CONSOLES]
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t data_sem;
} OS_impl_console_internal_record_t
...
void OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    size_t                        StartPos;
    size_t                        EndPos;
    size_t                        WriteSize;
    OS_console_internal_record_t *console;

    console  = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_console_table, *token);
    StartPos = console->ReadPos;
    EndPos   = console->WritePos;

    OS_BSP_Lock_Impl();

    while (StartPos != EndPos)
    {
        if (StartPos > EndPos)
        {
            /* handle wrap */
            WriteSize = console->BufSize - StartPos;
        }
        else
        {
            WriteSize = EndPos - StartPos;
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(&console->BufBase[StartPos], WriteSize);

        StartPos += WriteSize;
        if (StartPos >= console->BufSize)
        {
            /* handle wrap */
            StartPos = 0;
        }
    }

    OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl();

    /* Update the global with the new read location */
    console->ReadPos = StartPos;
}
...
extern OS_SharedGlobalVars_t OS_SharedGlobalVars
...
#define OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER 0xABADC0DE
...
typedef union
{
    void *           opaque_arg;
    OS_ArgCallback_t arg_callback_func;
    osal_id_t        id;
    osal_index_t     idx;
} OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONSOLE 0x0C
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other fragments in the function are not reported because they are declarations, comments, or clearly necessary operations that affect program behaviour or resource handling and therefore are unlikely to be dead code. Examples include the variable declarations (local, token), the union/type-punning comment (which documents intentional use), the macro-based table access definitions and related helper functions shown in the additional code (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, etc.), and the loop body structure that coordinates output and semaphore waiting. The external functions and macros used (OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit/Finish, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken/Cancel, OS_BSP_Lock_Impl/Unlock_Impl, OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl) perform observable side effects (locking, I/O, object token management) so their invocations themselves are not considered dead without deeper context. Therefore only the listed lines are flagged for investigation as potential dead-code candidates; all other lines are retained because they are necessary for correct locking, token/object lifecycle, I/O, or control-flow and cannot be removed without changing program behaviour.
